data.title: Windows File Explorer context menu broken
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)? Not applicable
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)? Not applicable
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?  It's not at all clear where the Windows context menu code would be.  Atom? Electron?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

The update to v1.10 seems to have broken the Atom action in the context menu in Windows Explorer. 

_This may be due to the Windows 10 Anniversary update which happened at the same time as the atom update._  However, uninstalling and reinstalling atom did not fix it so I suspect that the issue with with atom
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Install v1.10 or update to it
2. Open Windows Explorer
3. Right-click on a file

**Expected behavior:**

The context menu should have green Atom icon next to "Open with Atom"
Selecting "Open with Atom" should open the file in atom.

**Actual behavior:**

The context menu icon is a generic one, not atom's green icon.
Selecting "Open with Atom" opens a Windows dialog saying, "How do you want to open this file" with a list of potential programs, of which atom is somewhere down the list.
### Versions

atom 1.10.2
Windows 10 Anniversary update version 1607 build 14393.105

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

data.body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

In macOS you can have an application running without having any application window running. This is the case for Atom. However, if you do `File -> Open` or `File -> Open Project Folder` when Atom does not have a window open then no dialog window appears
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Launch Atom (on macOS)
2. Close window (so that the app is still running but has no windows open)
3. do the command `File -> Open`

**Expected behaviour:** A dialog window to appear to open a file which will also open a new window

**Actual behaviour:** Nothing
### Versions

Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.4

data.title: Scroll to top/bottom can fail, due to mouse wheel nullifying programatic scrolling
data.body:
### Description

(Tested on Mac OS X 10.11.6)

There seems to be some odd behavior relating to how user interaction-based scrolling, and programatic scrolling, interact when occurring simultaneously. Specifically, if a user is scrolling in a text editor using the mouse wheel, programatic scroll commands (such as "scroll to top", "scroll to bottom", and so on) will move the cursor, but not change the scroll position of the editor.

While this might sound like the proper behavior, it doesn't conform to standard scroll behavior of other Mac OS X apps (for example, Safari, or Text Editor). 

It also leads to some odd edge cases: I use BetterTouchTool to map the "three finger swipe up" gesture on my trackpad to send a "home" key input. This allows me to swipe up with three fingers, and jump to the top of the document in most apps. However, this fails in Atom, because Atom starts to scroll as soon as I move my three fingers on the touchpad, it ignores the "home" key event subsequently sent by BTT when it registers the gesture.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Begin scrolling within a text editor using the touchpad
2. While still scrolling, press "cmd-down" (mapped to "scroll to bottom" by default)

**Expected behavior:** The editor (and cursor) jumps to the end of the document.

**Actual behavior:** The cursor is moved to the end of the document, but the editor doesn't move.
### Versions

```
Mac OS X: 10.11.6

Atom    : 1.11.0-beta5
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.10.0
```

data.title: Incorrect indentation when using multi-line snippets
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Snippet indentation is incorrect. I have the following snippet:

```
'.source.js':
  'React method':
    'prefix': 'rm',
    'body': """
    $1 = ($2) => {
      $3
    };
    """
```

I open a .js file and type "rm" then hit tab and fill it in.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

Expected result: (e.g.):

``` js
  testMethod = () => {
    this.doSomething();
  };
```

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

``` js
  testMethod = () => {
     this.doSomething();
   };
```
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

```

```

data.title: Right clicking on text document content causes 'hang message
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

If you open a file, right click on the contents of the opened file. Wait less than a minute it will cause a 'Atom has crashed' message to pop up and a option to wait. Clicking wait unsticks the application.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. open txt file
2. right click on contents of file
3. stare at the dialog window (showing undo/redo etc) for a minute
4. see 'warning' able application being unresponsive

**Expected behavior:** Nothing

**Actual behavior:** See above
### Versions

Atom    : 1.10.1
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python
git 1.9.5.msysgit.0
visual studio

Windows 7 SP1

data.title: Mac context menu opens underneath cursor, breaking Apple OS X HIG
data.body:
### Description

On Mac OS X, the context menu (i.e., the right click menu) in Atom opens directly under your cursor, rather than a few pixels to the right, as is standard in OS X. As a result, after you right-click, the first option in the menu is already selected, and left-clicking (without moving the mouse) will select this menu item, rather than dismissing the menu.

Apple's official [OS X Human Interface Guidelines](https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/OSXHIGuidelines/ContextualMenus.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/20000957-CH30-SW1) specifically state:

> **Don’t set a default item in a contextual menu.** If the user opens the menu and closes it without selecting anything, no action should occur.

While this doesn't directly mention menu location in relation to the cursor, it's implied by saying that the user should have to take action to select a menu item, and without that, no action should take place. 

You can see the correct behavior in any number of other OS X apps. For example, in Safari, if you right-click on a page, the context menu appears a few pixels to the right of the cursor. This way, no menu item is selected until the user takes action and moves the cursor right. If you right-click, then click without moving the mouse, no action will be selected, and the menu will be dismissed. 
### Steps to Reproduce
1. In Atom, open some file to edit.
2. Right-click inside the editor _without moving the cursor_.
3. Left-click, again without moving the cursor.

**Expected behavior:** The context menu should be dismissed without any menu item being selected, or action being taken.

**Actual behavior:** The "Undo" action is selected/acted on.
### Versions

```
Mac OS X: 10.11.6

Atom    : 1.10.0
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.10.0
```

data.title: Spell check markers do not reposition when soft wrapped and closing a split pane
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Closing a split pane when soft wrapped does not cause the spell check markers to get repositioned. Doing almost any action while in this state causes them to reposition correctly. Actions that cause them to reposition are: resize the Atom window, click in the `TextEditor`, scroll the `TextEditor`, switch to another tab and back, use the arrow keys to move the cursor.
I can reproduce this with all themes in safe mode on both Windows 10 and Windows 7.

Discovered and discussed over in https://github.com/atom/language-gfm/issues/167#issuecomment-244906162 where @nathansobo told me to open a new issue.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom in safe mode.
2. Ensure you have `Soft Wrap` enabled.
3. Ensure you have `spell-check` enabled.
4. Copy [this file](https://gist.githubusercontent.com/Ben3eeE/6b9a8d5c3fbdd38bda3b70b63617b280/raw/77e0fc174f27160e82bd3c27f2d8182771770fb8/gistfile1.txt) into a new untitled `TextEditor` 
5. Split the pane right and resize the Atom window so there is soft wrapping.
6. Close the right pane that you just opened.

Gif of reproduction Windows 7 safe mode:
![split pane close](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/18268989/8712b448-7426-11e6-814c-adf8b998e353.gif)

Inspect markers in dev tools:
![markers in dev tools](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/18305056/0283dc00-74e6-11e6-82f9-70e28581873d.png)

**Expected behavior:** Spell check markers to be correctly positioned.

**Actual behavior:** Spell check markers are incorrectly positioned. Doing anything like moving the cursor, clicking in the pane causes them to reposition correctly.
### Versions
##### Atom 1.11.0-beta4 on Windows 10
###### atom --version

```
Atom    : 1.11.0-beta4
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75

node 4.4.5

visual studio
```

data.title: Git integration holds locks on pack files in .git directory
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

When I open a project directory in Atom which is under git source control, the git integration in Atom holds file locks on various files in the .git directory of the project.  This breaks git commands that modify the pack files, like `git gc`. When running `git gc`, I see errors like the following:

```
Unlink of file '.git/objects/pack/pack-0cca48411464b8ef80a288f080d3d8eef5321ae3.pack' failed. Should I try again? (y/n)
```

Using [Process Explorer](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/bb896653), I was able to track down the file lock to the atom.exe process.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open project directory in Atom that is under git source control
2. Perform enough commits to the git repo that a garbage collection will write new .pack and .idx files
3. Try running `git gc` with Atom open

OR
1. Open project directory in Atom that is under git source control
2. Observe atom.exe process holding open handles to .git files in Process Explorer

**Expected behavior:** Atom does not hold open handles on .git files

**Actual behavior:** Atom holds open handles on .git files
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

OS is Win 10.0.10240

data.title: Wait for windows' state to be saved before closing the app or any window
data.body:
This fixes a test failure on #12300 where the new Electron version prevents state from being serialized.

Previously, we used to save the window's state in the renderer process `beforeunload` event handler: because of the synchronous nature of event handlers and the asynchronous design of IndexedDB, this could potentially not save anything if windows close fast enough to prevent IndexedDB from committing the pending transaction containing the state. (Ref.: https://mzl.la/2bXCXDn)

With this commit, we will intercept the `before-quit` events on `electron.app` and the `close` event on `BrowserWindow` (which will fire respectively before quitting the application and before closing a
window), and prevent them from performing the default action. We will then ask each renderer process to save its state and, finally, close the window and/or the app when the IndexedDB transaction completes.

/cc: @atom/core @thomasjo

data.title: Fix height when splitting panes

When splitting a pane **down**, the height isn't evenly split in half, just after resizing the tree-view. Or when some other style is changed in DevTools.. maybe if the change triggers a reflow?

data.title: "New update" has wrong version shown if you let the update download first
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

When at Atom update is available, I usually don't notice the blue squirrel button immediately. By the time I do click it, if I wait long enough (to let it download?), then Atom always shows me that the update is to the current version number that I'm already at.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Start up Atom when an update is available.
2. Don't click the blue squirrel icon immediately. Leave Atom running for a while (to give it time to finish downloading the update first maybe? If that's the case, then I assume "Automatically download updates" must be on.)
3. Click blue squirrel icon.

**Expected behavior:**

The current version and a link to the current version's release notes should be shown at the top, and then the "New update" section should show the version number of the new update

**Actual behavior:**

The current version and a link to the current version's release notes is shown at the top, and then the "New update" section shows my current version and a link to its release notes instead of the update's version.

If I restart Atom and then immediately click the blue squirrel button, the about page will say that it's downloading the new update and then always show the correct version number.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.10.0
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.10
git 2.9.3

data.title: Atom closes files not present in current branch
data.body:
Consider this workflow: I have new files created in a branch. I then stash my unstaged files and checkout another branch to quickly rebase or something. When I return to the original branch, I must reopen my stashed files in Atom because it considered them deleted and closed the tab. In reality they were just in another branch. 

Other editors I've used (Sublime, Coda) keep the tab open. Both of them pretend the file still exists and recreates it if saved. Try saving the deleted or open file from another branch and Coda also warns the user the file does not exist:
![screen shot 2016-09-06 at 6 50 24 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6657634/18293814/22e062f8-7463-11e6-94ba-43a5b94bf060.png)

Regardless of the approach, it is a missing functionality in Atom. My workaround is to close Atom, switch branch, `git` whatever i got to, then checkout again and reopen Atom, so it preserves my open, still existent file that was never really deleted.

This issue partially opposes #5394. Keeping deleted files open and showing a warning message like the one in Coda when saving would resolve this issue and would prevent accidental re-saving of truly deleted files.

data.title: Clip to next boundary when seeking iterator to the middle of a text tag
data.body:
Fixes #12609.

Previously, when calling `TokenizedBufferIterator.seek` with a position that lied within a text tag, we advanced the iterator by the extent of that tag without, however, consuming it. Hence, when calling `moveToSuccessor` afterward, we would consume that tag and advance the iterator again, thus effectively moving it twice and causing issues like the aforementioned one.

An option could be to clip to the left of the textual tag without consuming it. However, this would be a little odd with respect to the current contract of (`DisplayLayer` and) `seek`, whose promise is to move the iterator to a position that is greater or equal than the one asked by the caller.

Therefore, with this pull-request, we are changing the behavior of `seek` in this particular scenario to consume the tag in question and process all its siblings until a tag boundary is finally found. This ensures that the above contract is always respected, while still preserving the "seek to leftmost tag boundary" semantics (i.e. notice how in the changed test case, calling `seek` with `Point(0, 1)` is the same as calling it with `Point(0, 3)`).

/cc: @nathansobo

### Description

The error is described here:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/39282229/cant-install-packages-in-atom-in-app-or-cmd

> I'm trying to install linter for atom, however both in the app and in cmd I get:
> 
> INFO: Could not find files for the given pattern(s).
> 
> `\Java\jre7\bin";C:\Program Files (x86)\QuickTime\QTSystem\;C:\WINDOWS\system32;C:\WINDOWS;C:\WINDOWS\System32\Wbem;C:\WINDOWS\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\;C:\Program Files (x86)\ATI Technologies\ATI.ACE\Core-Static;C:\Program Files (x86)\AMD\ATI.ACE\Core-Static;C:\Program Files (x86)\Brackets\command;C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\120\Tools\Binn\;C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\Windows Performance Toolkit\;C:\Program Files (x86)\GtkSharp\2.12\bin;" was unexpected at this time.`
> 
> And I honestly don't know what that means, but I've tried searching for an answer and I can't find it. "atom -v" returns the version (1.10.0), "apm -v" returns the above, as well as any apm command. "where apm" returns
> 
> C:\Users\JM\AppData\Local\atom\bin\apm
> 
> C:\Users\JM\AppData\Local\atom\bin\apm.cmd

Though I am hitting this error in the Atom Packages search.

Looks like `atom.cmd` breaks on the second occurrence of the closing parenthesis: `"C:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jdk1.8.0_60\bin"` or on the first after `Git\cmd`, don't know for sure. I've checked by removing both parentheses and just the closing one, it did run without the error both times.

Somehow related to Java installation or update.
### Steps to Reproduce

Windows 7, Atom 1.10.0.

The full `Path` variable contents:

```
C:\ProgramData\Oracle\Java\javapath;%SystemRoot%\system32;%SystemRoot%;%SystemRoot%\System32\Wbem;%SYSTEMROOT%\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\;C:\Program Files\TortoiseGit\bin;C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\cmd;C:\Users\user\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python35-32\Scripts\;C:\Users\user\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python35-32\;C:\Users\user\AppData\Roaming\npm;D:\_babak\_programs\apache-ant-1.9.6\bin;"C:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jdk1.8.0_60\bin";D:\_babak\_programs\code_swarm\bin;C:\Program Files\TortoiseHg\;C:\Users\user\AppData\Local\atom\bin;D:\_babak\_programs\watchman;%NVM_HOME%;%NVM_SYMLINK%;"C:\Program Files\Java\jre1.8.0_74\bin";"C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.8.0_74\bin"
```

`where git` gives:

```
C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\cmd\git.exe
```

`apm.cmd` contents:

```
@echo off
setlocal enabledelayedexpansion

:: Try to find git.exe in path
for /f "tokens=*" %%G in ('where git') do set "apm_git_path=%%~dpG"
if not defined apm_git_path (
  :: Try to find git.exe in GitHub Desktop, oldest first so we end with newest
  for /f "tokens=*" %%d in ('dir /b /s /a:d /od "%LOCALAPPDATA%\GitHub\PortableGit*"') do (
    if exist %%d\cmd\git.exe set apm_git_path=%%d\cmd
  )
  :: Found one, add it to the path
  if defined apm_git_path set "Path=!apm_git_path!;%PATH%"
)

set maybe_node_gyp_path=%~dp0\..\node_modules\node-gyp\bin\node-gyp.js
if exist %maybe_node_gyp_path% (
  set npm_config_node_gyp=%maybe_node_gyp_path%
)

if exist "%~dp0\node.exe" (
  "%~dp0\node.exe" "%~dp0/../lib/cli.js" %*
) else (
  node.exe "%~dp0/../lib/cli.js" %*
)
```

**Expected behavior:**

The Atom Package search works without errors.

**Actual behavior:**

`Searching for "..." failed.`
### Versions

Electron: 0.37.8

data.title: Special "light" mode for fast git start
data.body:
I would really like to use Atom for editing commit messages of git, however I have one big problem: With a lot of packages installed Atom is just _veery_ slow.

This is why I'd propose to add a special `git-start` mode of Atom. This is how it should work:
When Atom is already started it should just work as usual, opening a new tab and let the user type in the commit message.
However when Atom is not already started it should just load a "light" version of Atom, where it does only load Atom (& most core packages) and `language-git` (and possibly some packages the user can configure manually), but not anything else. The reason is simple: In 80% of these situation the user will close Atom anyway directly after finishing writing the commit message, so there is not need to load packages for Python, PHP or so...

Of course it would be awesome if a user could load the missing packages afterwards when they finished writing the commit message, so that they can even go on using Atom without having to restart it.
